Football being over and done and
lacrosse having been started on its
way rejoicing, the track team steps
into the limelight on the centre of
the athletic stage.
The football
team covered itself with glory, the
lacrosse team begins to look good,
and the track team has the brightest
prospect in years.
The season starts in real earnest
after the first of the year and during the months following and up to
Easter there is some indoor meet
Practically every week. After the
Easter holidays the open- season
comes and dual meets are being arranged with Virginia, Dickinson,
Haverford and Lehigh—the two former at Charlottesville and Carlisle;
the two latter at Homewood. Aside
from our own indoor games the important winter events for the team
will be the Fifth Regiment meet and
the Indoor South Athletic Championships.
The Relay Team will probably be
composed of the same men as it was
last year, Stollenwerck, Hunter,
Bridgeman, and Fulton, though
Horrox at the medical school may
succeed in taking a place in the
quartet. He comes from Williams,
where he captained their track team
and is said to have a time better
than 5o seconds for the quarter.
Morton, who ran this distance at
Amherst is also out and it is not unlikely that he may also run on the
relay. Other medical men on the
squad are "Babe"
Michael for
weights, Stevenson at the hurdles,
and Reid at the shot and hammer.
The following men from the undergraduate department have reported to Captain Stollenwerck and
Coach Hoffman: Tappan, jumps,
Wolfe, mile; H. Stewart, Jumps;
Todes, dashes; Lee, mile; Webb,
Jumps; Ray, quarter; Clift, half;
Pitper, dashes; Sigmund, clashes;
Getz, dashes, and Gillet, distances.
The team is indeed fortunate in
, again having secured the services
of such an excellent coach as William E. Hoffman, whose duties as
city chemist it was at one time feared would prevent his taking charge
of the candidates again this season. Mr. Hoffman was a star on
our track some years ago and he
has turned out some record breakers for the team.

A mass meeting of the track team
candidates was held last Tuesday in
the Trophy Room. It was characterized by the high degree of enthuiasm manifested by all who attended.
Captain Stollenwerck first called
called on Coach William E. Hoffman, who said that never had he
known or heard tell of such a large

and worked hard would be entered
in meets and taken out of town on
trips even if at first they did not
show up to particular advantage.
"Joe" England, a former track
star, was the next to speak. He was
most optimistic about the team's
prospects and told something about
the principle meei s in which the
R.
team will compete this year.
Curzon Hoffman, Jr., Dr. George
Scholl and Dr. Radcliffe were also
present and gave a few words of encouragement and advice to the candidates on behalf of the Alumni.
"Dutch" Bryer, the champion
cross country man of the State,
made a plea for cross country running on the ground that it cannot
be equalled for "putting legs under
a man and filling his chest with
lungs." "Ev" Bridgeman told the
candidates about some of the good
times the track team had last season, and "Jimmie" Hunter spoke on
the importance of the team working
as a unit and the disadvantages ot
striving for personal honors.
Captain Stollenwerck spoke a few
words expressing his gratification at
the large number of candidates for
the track and his confidence in the
successful season that lays before
the team. After the close of the

was just beginning to be whispered in

seven million dollars for educational
purposes, with but one stipulation —
that it should be used for a "University, and a hospital"—he began a new
chapter in the educational history of
America.

faculty which should represent this
new idea, and the halls and lecture

Back in 1876 the word UniversiLy
was just beginning to be whispered in
this country, and always with a conscious tone, by college men in speaking of their "Alma Mater."
When Johns Hopkins gave away
seven million dollars for educational
purposes, with but one stipulation —
that it should be used for a "University, and a hospital"—he began a new
chapter in the educational history of
America.
The first problem was to collect a
faculty which should represent this
new idea, and the halls and lecture
rooms of Europe and America were
searched by the late Dr Gilman. The
original faculty of our University
were men who were pioneers, blazing
out the trail, whose history is the 11.story of this subject: Sylvester in
mathematics, Rowland the great physicist, Adams the historian, Morris
the genial classicist, Gildersleeve the
Grecian, and Remsen in chemistry. Is
it any wonder that Johns Hopkins
leapt to the first rank?

universities in America. She was a
pioneer in the field of graduate study,
of original research. Our past history has been one of brilliant achievement. Our biological laboratory, the
first in this country, soon attracted the
eyes of the world.

a home in our Medical School. The
work in chemistry was brilliant and

Mr. David G. Hogarth, M. A.,
curator of the Ashmolean Museum,
of the University of Oxford, England, lectured last Tuesday afternoon in McCoy Hall, on the Hittite
Discoveries in Relation to Early
Greek History. Mr. Hogarth spoke
about different Hittite monuments
and sculpture, and also of the influence that Hittite art had on the early
Greeks.
Mr. Hogarth had many lantern
slides showing the strange forms
and peculiarities of early Hittite
sculpture. One very interesting picture was that of a female face, which
was carved on the side of a mountain. This face was placed in such
a position that a thin stream of
water, probably a mountain stream.
trickled incessantly over it. It is
supposed to be that of a Hittite goddess, and since the face was always
covered with water, the Hittites
called it their "Weeping Niobe."
Many other pictures of great interest were shown.
The lecture was held under the
auspices of the Baltimore Society
of the Archaeological Institute of
America, on the Charles Eliot Norton memorial lectureship foundation.
